Quotation Name: Guido Reni, like his own eye's apple Guarded long the treasure-book…
Quotation Content: Guido Reni, like his own eye's apple  Guarded long the treasure-book and loved it.  Guido Reni dying, all Bologna 30 Cried, and the world cried too, 'Ours, the treasure!'  Suddenly, as rare things will, it vanished.
Riferimento-Bibliografico: Browning, Robert (1855). “One Word More”, Men and Women, in The Poems edited By John Pettigrew.

Quotation Name: The last descent, however, that brings you upon Bologna, is very strik…
Quotation Content: The last descent, however, that brings you upon Bologna, is very striking; for not only does it display with great and good effect the broad city of Bologna with the river Rino, (lying as usual in a bed a great deal too big for it,) but it exhibits the enormous plains of Lombardy stretching forward with a vastness that is almost sublime in its unvarying flatness.
Riferimento-Bibliografico: Trollope, Frances Milton (1842). A Visit to Italy.

Quotation Name: have perhaps given the city a more widely-extended and enduring fame t…
Quotation Content: have perhaps given the city a more widely-extended and enduring fame than all the learning of her University .... and yet that this venerable seat of erudition ranks high among the highest it were sad ignorance to doubt .... moreover, there is no university I believe, that has shown so much gentle condescension to the ladies; more than one having been honoured by receiving the diploma of a doctor's degree from it
Riferimento-Bibliografico: Trollope, Frances Milton (1842). A Visit to Italy.

Quotation Name: The Campo Santo of Bologna is the most spleen did burying-ground, in p…
Quotation Content: The Campo Santo of Bologna is the most spleen did burying-ground, in point of size, in the world; and so complicated have its numerous courts and quadrangles become by repeated additions, that the guide charged our party to keep together, that none might lose their way, and so run the risk of being locked up within this enormous enclosure. But, excepting its size, it has, I think, little to boast of .... On first entering the cloister that surrounds the courts, I was greatly struck with the magnificent abundance of sculptures which met my eye; but, on drawing nearer to the objects of my admiration, I perceived that the most splendid looking amongst them were but frescoes in imitation of rilievi.
Riferimento-Bibliografico: Trollope, Frances Milton (1842). A Visit to Italy.

Quotation Name: From the Campo Santo we ordered the carriage, which we had hired at th…
Quotation Content: From the Campo Santo we ordered the carriage, which we had hired at the hotel for our morning excursion, to drive us to the celebrated Church of La Madonna della Guardia, which we had been particularly desired not to omit seeing, and which we knew commanded a view remarkable for its enormous extent.
Riferimento-Bibliografico: Trollope, Frances Milton (1842). A Visit to Italy.

Quotation Name: We turned that corner and perceived another long reach of arches, towe…
Quotation Content: We turned that corner and perceived another long reach of arches, towering before us at an angle of about forty-five degrees, and then again turning out of sight. But we were persevering people, exemplary in the patient endurance of fatigue, and pretty considerably ardent in the pursuit of what we wished to see ; .... so, on we went, on, on, on ; up, up, up, under these terrible arcades, which seemed, as if by wicked magic, to be long drawn out, longer and steeper, the more we toiled. And often did the party stop and take panting counsel together, as to whether it were wisest to turn back or to proceed; but the onward voices carried it; and it was good at that moment to remember that when the poet says “Hope leads us on,” he adds “nor leaves us when we die; ” an assurance particularly consolatory at a moment when the act of going on seemed so very likely to end in dying.... But it takes an immense quantity of burning sun and steep climbing to kill a party of English sight-seers; and, strange to say, we found ourselves under the last of six hundred and forty arches which had stretched over above two miles of excessively steep ground, not only alive, but sufficiently in possession of our senses to be conscious that the atmosphere of suffocating heat, through which we had climbed up this sheltering hill, was changed upon our thus reaching the top of it into a tempest of wind before which it was exceedingly difficult to stand.
Codes: ESPERIENZA::Fatica  LINGUA::English  LU::Portici::Portico di San Luca
Riferimento-Bibliografico: Trollope, Frances Milton (1842). A Visit to Italy.

Quotation Name: The situation of this church and convent is one very rarely equalled f…
Quotation Content: The situation of this church and convent is one very rarely equalled for isolated grandeur of elevation. The abruptness of the ascent gives the view of the city and surrounding country unbroken by any intervening objects in the foreground. It was like looking at a landscape at the Diorama.
Riferimento-Bibliografico: Trollope, Frances Milton (1842). A Visit to Italy.

Quotation Name: This singular erection is the pious labour of the citizens of Bologna,…
Quotation Content: This singular erection is the pious labour of the citizens of Bologna, every class contributing a sum of money towards it; as we learnt by inscriptions placed at intervals between the arches, stating, that such and such a number of them had been erected at the cost of the tailors, or the tinkers, or the shoe-makers, or the servants, of the town .... not a trade or profession of any kind being omitted.
Codes: LINGUA::English  LU::Portici::Portico di San Luca  TEM::Cittadini-di-Bologna
Riferimento-Bibliografico: Trollope, Frances Milton (1842). A Visit to Italy.

Quotation Name: One of these bending towers called “La Carisenda,” is alluded to by Da…
Quotation Content: One of these bending towers called “La Carisenda,” is alluded to by Dante, and proves clearly enough that it was as obviously out of the perpendicular above five hundred years ago, as it is now.... He says, speaking of the giant who bore Virgil and himself away, that in the act of taking them— “Qual pare a reguarder la Carisenda,” for so he writes it, “Sotto 'l chinato, quand' un nuvol vada;” and because he has thus named it, the old tower is popularly called “Dante's tower” to this day.
Riferimento-Bibliografico: Trollope, Frances Milton (1842). A Visit to Italy.

Quotation Name: The majestic Neptune, too, of its great and immortal John, made a forc…
Quotation Content: The majestic Neptune, too, of its great and immortal John, made a forcible impression on my memory, by its stupendous dignity of size and aspect;
Riferimento-Bibliografico: Trollope, Frances Milton (1842). A Visit to Italy.

Quotation Name: all I remember of the general effect of the city is, the gloomy air gi…
Quotation Content: all I remember of the general effect of the city is, the gloomy air given by its low-browed arcades, which, though a very rational mode of building in a country where shade is so much required, can only contribute to beauty when constructed on as grand a scale
Riferimento-Bibliografico: Trollope, Frances Milton (1842). A Visit to Italy.

Quotation Name: Instead of two days, I believe that wise people would remain at least…
Quotation Content: Instead of two days, I believe that wise people would remain at least two months at Bologna; and even then would probably leave it without having seen half the precious things it has to show.
Riferimento-Bibliografico: Trollope, Frances Milton (1842). A Visit to Italy.

Quotation Name: The Sta. Cecilia of the Bolognese Gallery has that in her countenance…
Quotation Content: The Sta. Cecilia of the Bolognese Gallery has that in her countenance which, though few can fail to see it, and more or less appreciate its matchless purity, required for the conception of it a mind little less elevated than that of Dante, when he says that he saw Beatrice dare to look upon the sun.... “Aquila sì non gli s’affisse unquanco.” Who but Raphael, and the one or two incomprehensible bright ones who make part of the same mysterious galaxy, would have thought of mixing such perfection of innocent simplicity with such fearless elevation of spirit ?
Riferimento-Bibliografico: Trollope, Frances Milton (1842). A Visit to Italy.

Quotation Name: We traversed a champagne country in our way to Bologna, whose richness…
Document: William Beckford - Dreams, Waking thoughts and Incidents- In a Series of Letters from Various Parts of Europe
Quotation Content: We traversed a champagne country in our way to Bologna, whose richness and fertility increased in proportion as we drew near that celebrated mart of lap-dogs and sausages. A chain of hills commands the city, variegated with green enclosures and villas innumerable, almost every one of which has its grove of chestnuts and cypresses.
Riferimento-Bibliografico: Beckford, William (1780). Dreams, Waking thoughts and Incidents: In a Series of Letters from Various Parts of Europe.

Quotation Name: On the highest acclivity of this range appears the magnificent convent…
Document: William Beckford - Dreams, Waking thoughts and Incidents- In a Series of Letters from Various Parts of Europe
Quotation Content: On the highest acclivity of this range appears the magnificent convent of Madonna del Monte, embosomed in wood, and joined to the town by a corridor a league in length. This vast portico, ascending the steeps and winding amongst the thickets, sometimes concealed and sometimes visible, produces an effect wonderfully grand and singular.

Quotation Name: The church (St. Padrona) in which is this meridian-line on the floor,…
Document: Adam Walker – Ideas suggested on the spot in a Late Excursion through Flanders, Germany, France and (Italy
Quotation Content: The church (St. Padrona) in which is this meridian-line on the floor, is of modernized Gothic—very large—clean— and magnificent in decoration. Its outside would have been equally magnificent, had it been finished as it is begun—but all above the doors is a mere screen of brick, which seems to reproach the pre sent generation for not finishing what their forefathers had so beautifully begun
Riferimento-Bibliografico: Walker, Adam (1787). Ideas suggested on the spot in a Late Excursion through Flanders, Germany, France and Italy.

Quotation Name: But chusing to have a general view of the town before I entered into i…
Document: Adam Walker – Ideas suggested on the spot in a Late Excursion through Flanders, Germany, France and (Italy
Quotation Content: But chusing to have a general view of the town before I entered into its minutiae, there are twelve gates, and an old wall, with the inner arches mostly filled up-and a deep ditch on the outside—no regular fortification. On one side of the city, nothing can be more beautiful—The hills rise in elegant curves, all covered with pretty houses, vineyards, and churches, so as to make a charming landscape. On three sides of the city it is a dead-flat, but rich in vines, corn, and flax.
Riferimento-Bibliografico: Walker, Adam (1787). Ideas suggested on the spot in a Late Excursion through Flanders, Germany, France and Italy.

Quotation Name: We then visited the School of Anatomy, in which one Lilli and his wife…
Document: Adam Walker – Ideas suggested on the spot in a Late Excursion through Flanders, Germany, France and (Italy
Quotation Content: We then visited the School of Anatomy, in which one Lilli and his wife have shewn a tolerable knowledge of the muscles and blood vessels, by their successful imitation of them in wax.
Riferimento-Bibliografico: Walker, Adam (1787). Ideas suggested on the spot in a Late Excursion through Flanders, Germany, France and Italy.

Quotation Name: We were then led into the School of Chymistry—here we found a great va…
Document: Adam Walker – Ideas suggested on the spot in a Late Excursion through Flanders, Germany, France and (Italy
Quotation Content: We were then led into the School of Chymistry—here we found a great variety of retorts, cucurbits, stills, &c. hung up for shew; but neither these, nor the various ill-contrived furnaces seem to have ever been used. No apparatus for catching those glasses that fly off from heated substances—and which make so very material a part of modern chymistry—nor one process of any sort going forward.
Riferimento-Bibliografico: Walker, Adam (1787). Ideas suggested on the spot in a Late Excursion through Flanders, Germany, France and Italy.

Quotation Name: The School of Philosophy (made famous by a female Professor, who died…
Document: Adam Walker – Ideas suggested on the spot in a Late Excursion through Flanders, Germany, France and (Italy
Quotation Content: The School of Philosophy (made famous by a female Professor, who died a few years ago) I was particularly wishful to see—sorry that in this I was also disappointed. Here we found a number of ill-made instruments (mostly on the plan of Gravesand's) nothing new, except a pretty large plate electrical machine. A new air-pump was just trying, with the two cylinders horizontal, and open in the old way, very clumsy, which extracted very slow, yet seemed tolerably staunch. On enquiring after the Observatory, we found it was out of order—so we just inspected some good models of ships, fortifications, &c. and took our leave.
Riferimento-Bibliografico: Walker, Adam (1787). Ideas suggested on the spot in a Late Excursion through Flanders, Germany, France and Italy.

Quotation Name: In Bologna there is perhaps the tallest tower, for its thickness, of a…
Document: Adam Walker – Ideas suggested on the spot in a Late Excursion through Flanders, Germany, France and (Italy
Quotation Content: In Bologna there is perhaps the tallest tower, for its thickness, of any in the world—it is 327 feet high—and its side on a medium, (for it grows smaller and smaller as one ascends) about 1o feet; it is called the Asinelli Tower, and is said to lean 3 } feet out of its perpendicular— it is of brick, and was built in 1109. Our heads must needs turn round on the top of this tower; –but we were amply re compensed by the view—we saw Milan, Ferrara, the Alps, Appenines, &c. and the town looked like a map beneath our feet.
Riferimento-Bibliografico: Walker, Adam (1787). Ideas suggested on the spot in a Late Excursion through Flanders, Germany, France and Italy.

Quotation Name: Besides the very tall tower, and near it, there stands another, about…
Document: Adam Walker – Ideas suggested on the spot in a Late Excursion through Flanders, Germany, France and (Italy
Quotation Content: Besides the very tall tower, and near it, there stands another, about the same thickness, but only 130 feet high, that has either been taken down, or never built higher; for its foundation on one side has given way so much, that it leans upwards of ten or twelve feet out of the perpendicular. One is almost afraid of walking near it—they are both of brick, and one wonders, why the weight does not break the lower bricks.
Riferimento-Bibliografico: Walker, Adam (1787). Ideas suggested on the spot in a Late Excursion through Flanders, Germany, France and Italy.

Quotation Name: Our next visit was to the Opera-house, which is said to be one of the…
Document: Adam Walker – Ideas suggested on the spot in a Late Excursion through Flanders, Germany, France and (Italy
Quotation Content: Our next visit was to the Opera-house, which is said to be one of the finest in Italy. It has five heights of galleries, each box bulging a little out of the general round, so as to make the whole have an airy look: its form is exactly like ours, but not so large—the pit is filled with loose benches.
Riferimento-Bibliografico: Walker, Adam (1787). Ideas suggested on the spot in a Late Excursion through Flanders, Germany, France and Italy.

Quotation Name: In the palace of Samperi, there are Colossal figures, in fresco, on th…
Document: Adam Walker – Ideas suggested on the spot in a Late Excursion through Flanders, Germany, France and (Italy
Quotation Content: In the palace of Samperi, there are Colossal figures, in fresco, on the ceiling of several rooms, that shew how much those artists were masters of the human figure, in every possible attitude. But Guido's picture of St. Peter and St. Paul struck me more than any picture I have seen, since I saw the martyrdom of St. Peter, by Rubens
Riferimento-Bibliografico: Walker, Adam (1787). Ideas suggested on the spot in a Late Excursion through Flanders, Germany, France and Italy.

Quotation Name: This town is famous for the richness of the soil that lies about it, a…
Document: Addison, Joseph. Remarks on Several Parts of Italy, & co. In the Years 1701, 1702, 1703. 1705
Quotation Content: This town is famous for the richness of the soil that lies about it, and the magnificence of its convents. It is likewise esteemed the third in Italy for pictures, as having been the school of Lombard painters.
Riferimento-Bibliografico: Addison, Joseph (1705). Remarks on Several Parts of Italy, & co. In the Years 1701, 1702, 1703.

Quotation Name: We passed a whole day very agreeably at Bologna: it is rich in picture…
Document: Beste - Italy as it Is; Or, Narrative of an English Family's Residence for Three Years in that Country
Quotation Content: We passed a whole day very agreeably at Bologna: it is rich in pictures both of its own and other schools. Fourscore of these pictures had made the journey to Paris—a sure proof of their merit. At the Academia delle Belle Arti is a collection which has its superior perhaps only at Florence
Riferimento-Bibliografico: Beste, Henry Digby (1828). Italy as it Is; Or, Narrative of an English Family's Residence for Three Years in that Country.

Quotation Name: Bologna is a fine old town: most of the streets have arcades, or what…
Document: Beste - Italy as it Is; Or, Narrative of an English Family's Residence for Three Years in that Country
Quotation Content: Bologna is a fine old town: most of the streets have arcades, or what are improperly called piazzas, on both sides—a shelter in this climate rather from the sun than from the rain, but in all cases a most useful and agree able arrangement, which would be oftener followed, but for the difficulty of reconciling the interest of the proprietors of the houses and that of the public.
Riferimento-Bibliografico: Beste, Henry Digby (1828). Italy as it Is; Or, Narrative of an English Family's Residence for Three Years in that Country.

Quotation Name: In the grand piazza, or square, are seen the admirable statues in bron…
Document: Beste - Italy as it Is; Or, Narrative of an English Family's Residence for Three Years in that Country
Quotation Content: In the grand piazza, or square, are seen the admirable statues in bronze, by John of Bologna, which adorn the fountain.
Riferimento-Bibliografico: Beste, Henry Digby (1828). Italy as it Is; Or, Narrative of an English Family's Residence for Three Years in that Country.

Quotation Name: The cathedral is under the invocation of St. Petronius, patron of the…
Document: Beste - Italy as it Is; Or, Narrative of an English Family's Residence for Three Years in that Country
Quotation Content: The cathedral is under the invocation of St. Petronius, patron of the city; he is in great veneration. I have seen money bearing his effigies. It is not uncommon in Italy to stamp current coin with the figures of saints: but, besides St. Petronius, I have met only with those of the Blessed Virgin, Sts. Peter and Paul, St. Andrew, and at Genoa, St. John the Baptist.
Riferimento-Bibliografico: Beste, Henry Digby (1828). Italy as it Is; Or, Narrative of an English Family's Residence for Three Years in that Country.

Quotation Name: The two towers or pillars of Bologna, one of which is so very tall, an…
Document: Beste - Italy as it Is; Or, Narrative of an English Family's Residence for Three Years in that Country
Quotation Content: The two towers or pillars of Bologna, one of which is so very tall, and the other stands awry, though remarked by every one, are remarkable only from their awkward look. They are of brick, and were they near a malt-kiln, or a smithy, they would not seem out of their places. It is, perhaps, more to be wondered at, that the inclined tower of Bologna does not fall, than that the tower of Pisa yet stands, being of larger bulk, of a circular form, and built of stone, all contributing to greater stability.
Riferimento-Bibliografico: Beste, Henry Digby (1828). Italy as it Is; Or, Narrative of an English Family's Residence for Three Years in that Country.

Document: Beste - Italy as it Is; Or, Narrative of an English Family's Residence for Three Years in that Country
Quotation Content: Bologna is in the very centre of the peninsula, and on that side of the Apennines on which lies its main extent of territory, and its ready communication with foreign nations.
Riferimento-Bibliografico: Beste, Henry Digby (1828). Italy as it Is; Or, Narrative of an English Family's Residence for Three Years in that Country.

Document: Drummond, Alexander. Travels Through Different Cities of Germany, Italy, Greece and Several Parts of Asia, as the Far as the Banks of the Euphrates, in a Series of Letters.
Quotation Content: Behind an altar, which stands in the middle of the church, is a very odd pedestal, above which we see a corinthian capital reversed, then a broken column, and over all a cross, part of which is the wood of the holy cross; and all these, they say, were brought from Jerusalem.
Riferimento-Bibliografico: Drummond, Alexander (1754). Travels Through Different Cities of Germany, Italy, Greece and Several Parts of Asia, as the Far as the Banks of the Euphrates, in a Series of Letters.

Quotation Name: The church of St. Petronio is gothic, built in an odd taste, which, ho…
Document: Drummond, Alexander. Travels Through Different Cities of Germany, Italy, Greece and Several Parts of Asia, as the Far as the Banks of the Euphrates, in a Series of Letters.
Quotation Content: The church of St. Petronio is gothic, built in an odd taste, which, however, is not without dignity. He is patron of the city, and under his statue we read this inscription: Prisca diu non prisca modo quae apparet imago Nos nova Petronij priscaque dona docet. 1708. I should not have wondered to see these lines dared three or four hundred years ago; but, to ﬁnd such gothic conceits of these days, gives a lamentable idea of modern taste. The great altar is extremely well designed, being an antique cupola, supported by four corinthian columns; upon the pavement is the Linea meridiana, a vertice ad tropicum capricorni, the sun darting through a small hole of the roof, when in the meridian, his rays strike the hour upon this graduated line, contrived by Mr. Cassini, and thereby their time is regulated; for their division is not by regular periods, like ours : their ﬁrst hour begins half an hour after sun set, and so they reckon on 'till four and twenty ; and therefore must be continualy altering their clocks and watches.
Riferimento-Bibliografico: Drummond, Alexander (1754). Travels Through Different Cities of Germany, Italy, Greece and Several Parts of Asia, as the Far as the Banks of the Euphrates, in a Series of Letters.

Quotation Content: there is the picture of an executioner in the act of beheading a faint, with a long sword, having a great deal of fury expressed in his countenance. In St. Gregory's church, there is an admirable piece by Lodovico Caracci, representing St. George and St. Margaret, who was relieved by his knightly arm ; together with the angel Gabriel above: and another excellent picture of St. Gregory performing a miracle, by Dionysius Calvert.

Document: Drummond, Alexander. Travels Through Different Cities of Germany, Italy, Greece and Several Parts of Asia, as the Far as the Banks of the Euphrates, in a Series of Letters.
Quotation Content: In the church of St. Francis, we see St. Anthony raising a person from the dead, extremely well painted by Laurentio Pacinelli; and the conversion of St. Paul, ﬁnely performed by Lodovico Caracci. The sculpture of two chappels, on the sides of the great altar, is very well executed; one being of Giallo & verdo antico: the cloisters are likewise beautifully adorned with busts of the monks of the Franciscan order; and, from the ﬂight of the stair-case, is a ſine prospect of two corridores, the one above the other. Here are no fewer than one hundred and ﬁfty fathers, who live like drones upon the industry of their fellow creatures: some of them, however, are men of real worth; and very sensible of the injury which accrues' to mankind from such idle institutions.
Riferimento-Bibliografico: Drummond, Alexander (1754). Travels Through Different Cities of Germany, Italy, Greece and Several Parts of Asia, as the Far as the Banks of the Euphrates, in a Series of Letters.

Quotation Name: Santo Salvator is a glorious building, having three noble chapels on e…
Document: Drummond, Alexander. Travels Through Different Cities of Germany, Italy, Greece and Several Parts of Asia, as the Far as the Banks of the Euphrates, in a Series of Letters.
Quotation Content: Santo Salvator is a glorious building, having three noble chapels on each side, before you come to the body of the nave, with a cupola over it; the whole is of the composite order, channelled, and the statuary is good.
Riferimento-Bibliografico: Drummond, Alexander (1754). Travels Through Different Cities of Germany, Italy, Greece and Several Parts of Asia, as the Far as the Banks of the Euphrates, in a Series of Letters.

Quotation Name: The Dominican church is very elegant: the lower columns of the vaultin…
Document: Drummond, Alexander. Travels Through Different Cities of Germany, Italy, Greece and Several Parts of Asia, as the Far as the Banks of the Euphrates, in a Series of Letters.
Quotation Content: The Dominican church is very elegant: the lower columns of the vaulting being ionic, the high pilasters corinthian, the Ornaments of stucco, and the whole executed in a very good taste. St. Andrew half undressed, for cruciﬁxion, by Rossi is a ﬁne piece; and the chappels that cross the nave are magnificent. Pope Pius V, by Felicio Torelli; and St. Jacinto, by Lodovico Caracci, must attract the eye of every man who knows any thing of A painting. St. Dominick's head and relics are preserved within an altar, but I could not see them, because he who kept the key was absent. The Dome church is really grand, and will be still more so, when the portico is ﬁnished;
Riferimento-Bibliografico: Drummond, Alexander (1754). Travels Through Different Cities of Germany, Italy, Greece and Several Parts of Asia, as the Far as the Banks of the Euphrates, in a Series of Letters.

Quotation Name: the whole is of the composite order, the capitals and modelion-cornish…
Document: Drummond, Alexander. Travels Through Different Cities of Germany, Italy, Greece and Several Parts of Asia, as the Far as the Banks of the Euphrates, in a Series of Letters.
Quotation Content: the whole is of the composite order, the capitals and modelion-cornish being very rich; but those by the gate are no more than paintings. On each ﬁde is a row of arched columns, or what are frequently called cloysters, and the complete nave seems to be well proportioned to the-length : the roof is arched and plain ; and one altar is adorned with giallo, verdo antico, and other stones of great value. There is a ﬁne altar erected by the heirs of Gregory V, and supported with giallo cointhian columns; there are four organs in the church, and two in the coir, supported by Tuscan pillars; three altars in architecture, the others in painting; though the deceptions have a good eﬀect: and as rich people die or superstitious zeal increases, real buildings will be reared in room of these appearances.
Riferimento-Bibliografico: Drummond, Alexander (1754). Travels Through Different Cities of Germany, Italy, Greece and Several Parts of Asia, as the Far as the Banks of the Euphrates, in a Series of Letters.

Quotation Name: The church of the Padri Philippini del Oratorio, is one of those that…
Document: Drummond, Alexander. Travels Through Different Cities of Germany, Italy, Greece and Several Parts of Asia, as the Far as the Banks of the Euphrates, in a Series of Letters.
Quotation Content: The church of the Padri Philippini del Oratorio, is one of those that (as l have already observed) please me, like a pretty, plain girl, by their neatness and white apparel. All the ornaments are corinthian, gilt, except the great altar, which is coloured, and two others, which are very elegant. Here is a young Jesus declaiming in the temple, and God above, with angels, by Albani; and it is observable of this great master, that there is not one of his pieces (at least I have seen none of them) without infant ﬁgures, either of angels, cupids, or mortals; and in these he was never equalled. Here is likewise a picture of Jesus, and Thomas feeling his wounds, by a fair lady called Teresia Mauratori, performed in a masterly manner.
Riferimento-Bibliografico: Drummond, Alexander (1754). Travels Through Different Cities of Germany, Italy, Greece and Several Parts of Asia, as the Far as the Banks of the Euphrates, in a Series of Letters.

Document: Drummond, Alexander. Travels Through Different Cities of Germany, Italy, Greece and Several Parts of Asia, as the Far as the Banks of the Euphrates, in a Series of Letters.
Quotation Content: In St. Margaret’s church, over the altar, is the picture of that female faint, with the virgin above, which is certainly a lovely figure, painted by Macini; there is likewise a very good Magdalen, by one of Guido’s scholars. St. Catharine receiving a young Jesus, by Permigiano, is an excellent piece :
Riferimento-Bibliografico: Drummond, Alexander (1754). Travels Through Different Cities of Germany, Italy, Greece and Several Parts of Asia, as the Far as the Banks of the Euphrates, in a Series of Letters.

Quotation Name: The cieling of St. Paul’s church is ﬁnely painted in fresco; the pilas…
Document: Drummond, Alexander. Travels Through Different Cities of Germany, Italy, Greece and Several Parts of Asia, as the Far as the Banks of the Euphrates, in a Series of Letters.
Quotation Content: The cieling of St. Paul’s church is ﬁnely painted in fresco; the pilasters are composite and channelled. A nativity, by Alexander Dorchi, and another by Cavedoni, are good pictures. On the great altar, are the statues of the faint and executioner, by Algardi, which might stand among the antiques. The father, and a dead Jesus, by Crespi ; St. Catharine de Bologna, a dead Jesus, by Marco Antonio Francischini; the church, by him and his scholars, together with an ascension, by Hannibal Caracci, are much to be regarded.
Riferimento-Bibliografico: Drummond, Alexander (1754). Travels Through Different Cities of Germany, Italy, Greece and Several Parts of Asia, as the Far as the Banks of the Euphrates, in a Series of Letters.

Document: Chancel, A.D. A New Journey over Europe. 1714
Quotation Content: to Fiorenzola is a very steep way, and to Loyan 14 Miles indifferent good, through the Mountains, both sides are full of chestnut Trees. From thence to Bolonia are counted 16 Miles, half the way we went through the Mountains, but the rest is very pleasant
Riferimento-Bibliografico: Chancel, Alexander D. (1714). A New Journey over Europe.

Quotation Name: here are several magnificent Churches, the greatest of which is that o…
Document: Chancel, A.D. A New Journey over Europe. 1714
Quotation Content: here are several magnificent Churches, the greatest of which is that of St. Petronius, in the Pavement of which is represented Cassinian's Meridional Line 220 Foot long, drawn in Copper; it will be one of the finest Churches In Europe, when finish’d.
Riferimento-Bibliografico: Chancel, Alexander D. (1714). A New Journey over Europe.

Quotation Name: This City lies at the foot of the Appennin Hills, which on the South-s…
Document: Chancel, A.D. A New Journey over Europe. 1714
Quotation Content: This City lies at the foot of the Appennin Hills, which on the South-side are cover'd with Vines, Olive, Fig, and other Fruit trees of all Sorts; on the other Side there are Fields abounding with Corn, Flax, and fine Rows of Mulberry trees, which nourish a Multitude of Silk-worms.
Riferimento-Bibliografico: Chancel, Alexander D. (1714). A New Journey over Europe.

Quotation Name: This City is so large, that it gave a convenient Entertainment to the…
Document: Chancel, A.D. A New Journey over Europe. 1714
Quotation Content: This City is so large, that it gave a convenient Entertainment to the Emperor Charles the 5th, with all the Princes and Ambassadors that attended him, with the Pope and 15 Cardinals, when the said Emperor was crown'd there in the Year 1529.
Riferimento-Bibliografico: Chancel, Alexander D. (1714). A New Journey over Europe.

Quotation Name: Here are many fine Palaces, private Houses, and a great Number of Towe…
Document: Chancel, A.D. A New Journey over Europe. 1714
Quotation Content: Here are many fine Palaces, private Houses, and a great Number of Towers, whereof that of Asinelli is as high as any in Europe
Riferimento-Bibliografico: Chancel, Alexander D. (1714). A New Journey over Europe.

Quotation Name: it is the second Town of the ecclesiastical State, and one of the larg…
Document: Chancel, A.D. A New Journey over Europe. 1714
Quotation Content: it is the second Town of the ecclesiastical State, and one of the largest, best peopled, and finest in Italy
Riferimento-Bibliografico: Chancel, Alexander D. (1714). A New Journey over Europe.

Quotation Name: Scarce any City in Europe could have entertain'd such a Multitude of P…
Document: Chancel, A.D. A New Journey over Europe. 1714
Quotation Content: Scarce any City in Europe could have entertain'd such a Multitude of Persons of the highest Rank, with their Attendants and Guards.
Riferimento-Bibliografico: Chancel, Alexander D. (1714). A New Journey over Europe.

Quotation Name: Stretching far as the eye can reach, is a chain of distant snow-capped…
Quotation Content: Stretching far as the eye can reach, is a chain of distant snow-capped Alps — the Adriatic, like a streak of light, is visible on the horizon ; while spread out below are the wide and fertile plains, with an occasional gleam from the winding Savenna. On this river stands the ancient city of Bologna, the capital of the most populous and flourishing of the States of the Church
Riferimento-Bibliografico: Dunbar, Margaret Juliana (1853). Art and Nature under an Italian Sky.

Quotation Name: On entering its wide and handsome streets, the first peculiarity the s…
Quotation Content: On entering its wide and handsome streets, the first peculiarity the stranger observes is the covered archway on each side, giving not only character to its streets, but affording a most grateful shade from the heat of the sun, and doubtless also protection from the storms of winter. At the same time one would suppose they must darken the shops and lower parts of the houses very dismally, especially in the old part of the city where the colonnades are low and heavy.
Riferimento-Bibliografico: Dunbar, Margaret Juliana (1853). Art and Nature under an Italian Sky.

Quotation Name: The Bolognese School of Painting is one of the most celebrated, and bo…
Quotation Content: The Bolognese School of Painting is one of the most celebrated, and boasts a constellation of the brightest genius. Passing over its earlier epochs, the period of its greatest glory began with the Caracci, in the sixteenth century, who introduced an entirely new style of painting, and were remarkable for the pious pupils they produced. Of these, the first and greatest was Domenichino, who has been called the second painter in the world — second only to Raphael. Scarcely inferior to him is Guido, who must be seen in Bologna to be thoroughly appreciated ; and Guercino, the pupil of Guido, who also belongs to this school.
Riferimento-Bibliografico: Dunbar, Margaret Juliana (1853). Art and Nature under an Italian Sky.

Quotation Name: As soon as we possibly could, our steps were directed to the Accademia…
Quotation Content: As soon as we possibly could, our steps were directed to the Accademia delle Belle Arte : it is a noble collection, admirably arranged, consisting chiefly of the native school. The works of the various artists are placed in a great measure chronologically.
Riferimento-Bibliografico: Dunbar, Margaret Juliana (1853). Art and Nature under an Italian Sky.

Quotation Name: Here is almost a single instance in which one could look at a painting…
Quotation Content: Here is almost a single instance in which one could look at a painting, where the subject is physical suffering, without disgust — the Martyrdom of St. Agnes, by Domenichino. It is a large picture containing a vast number of figures, all admirable, yet in nothing distracting the eye from the principal one.
Riferimento-Bibliografico: Dunbar, Margaret Juliana (1853). Art and Nature under an Italian Sky.

Quotation Name: To the treasures which more properly belong to Bologna, viz., the prod…
Quotation Content: To the treasures which more properly belong to Bologna, viz., the productions of her own scholars, has been added a precious gem of Raphael's — the Santa Cecilia. I was instantly struck with this countenance, not only with its expressive beauty, but the extraordinary likeness it bears to one most dear to me.
Riferimento-Bibliografico: Dunbar, Margaret Juliana (1853). Art and Nature under an Italian Sky.

Quotation Name: “The Massacre of the Innocents." In all respects it is the strongest c…
Quotation Content: “The Massacre of the Innocents." In all respects it is the strongest contrast to the " Samson." Terror, agony, wild despair, are each and all here portrayed. And while, my eye passed from one form of anguish to another, I felt ready to shrink before the stern determination of those fierce and pitiless soldiers, as if in living contact with them. I hid my face in my hands after gazing on one who, by the might of her mother's love, has succeeded in shielding as yet her precious baby by her own form. Oh I that relentless wretch 1 can he — will he — take the little one even from those bleeding arms !
Riferimento-Bibliografico: Dunbar, Margaret Juliana (1853). Art and Nature under an Italian Sky.

Quotation Name: Mr. Beckford calls Bologna " a city of puppy dogs and sausages," It wa…
Quotation Content: Mr. Beckford calls Bologna " a city of puppy dogs and sausages," It was probably this remark that made us curious to experiment upon the latter. Accordingly, when the waiter brought in tea, we ordered a portion of the renowned condiment. Alas for unsophisticated palates! The smell alone was nearly enough — the first mouthful was more than enough ; and ere a second was even contemplated, we changed our plates, and sent the vile combination of raw meat and garlic in disgrace from the room!
Riferimento-Bibliografico: Dunbar, Margaret Juliana (1853). Art and Nature under an Italian Sky.

Quotation Name: From Lojano to Pianoro, the descent is very abrupt, requiring addition…
Quotation Content: From Lojano to Pianoro, the descent is very abrupt, requiring additional drags upon the wheels. The views here, from various points of the road, are exceedingly striking.
Riferimento-Bibliografico: Dunbar, Margaret Juliana (1853). Art and Nature under an Italian Sky.

Quotation Name: Another masterpiece of this artist I find I have noted down, the Madon…
Quotation Content: Another masterpiece of this artist I find I have noted down, the Madonna del Rosario — by some considered to surpass even the St. Jerome in the Vatican.
Riferimento-Bibliografico: Dunbar, Margaret Juliana (1853). Art and Nature under an Italian Sky.

Quotation Name: I seldom think of these pictures unless accident recall them; whereas…
Quotation Content: I seldom think of these pictures unless accident recall them; whereas some there are which visit me in the dreamy hour of half unconscious musing, and which suggest the mental filling up of a history by the single page which they unfold. " Abraham dismissing Hagar " — " The Sibyl " in the Borghese Palace, are instances of this; — and now I have two more to add to these, which I saw in the Gallery of Bologna. The first is "Samson having obtained the Victory over the Philistines," by Guido. [...] Very reluctantly did I turn away from the majestic painting; yet but a few paces from it, I was arrested by another, which called forth the same sort of intense feeling, “The Massacre of the Innocents."
Riferimento-Bibliografico: Dunbar, Margaret Juliana (1853). Art and Nature under an Italian Sky.

Quotation Name: A brilliant moonlight evening tempted us out, wearied though we were.…
Quotation Content: A brilliant moonlight evening tempted us out, wearied though we were. The deep shadows underneath the arches of the Colonnade contrasted with the strong light beyond, and we remarked how fitting a time and place it seemed for the scene of some tale of the lurking assassin, with his gleaming stiletto.
Riferimento-Bibliografico: Dunbar, Margaret Juliana (1853). Art and Nature under an Italian Sky.

Quotation Name: This city, like Florence, offers a most agree able place of residence…
Quotation Content: This city, like Florence, offers a most agree able place of residence to the stranger, being well built and clean, and having wide arcades in all the streets, as a protection from the sun; the environs are rich and picturesque.
Riferimento-Bibliografico: Carne, John (1834). Letters from Switzerland and Italy, During a Late Tour by the Author of "Letters from the East" & "Travel in the East".

Quotation Name: The route to Bologna was in part wild and dreary. The country for a co…
Quotation Content: The route to Bologna was in part wild and dreary. The country for a considerable distance around the city is so richly and variously cultivated, that it looks more like a garden than the territory of peasants.
Riferimento-Bibliografico: Carne, John (1834). Letters from Switzerland and Italy, During a Late Tour by the Author of "Letters from the East" & "Travel in the East".

Quotation Name: The gallery of paintings near the university contains many of the fine…
Quotation Content: The gallery of paintings near the university contains many of the finest works in Italy, consisting chiefly of those of the Caracci, Guido, and Domenichino. The martyrdom of a christian family by the latter is a noble subject; a young and delicate lady, of great beauty, and richly dressed, is the chief figure, kneeling, her eyes and hands lifted towards Heaven for fortitude to bear her through the trial.
Riferimento-Bibliografico: Carne, John (1834). Letters from Switzerland and Italy, During a Late Tour by the Author of "Letters from the East" & "Travel in the East".

Quotation Name: The Samson of Guido is a noble picture; the figure is as large as life…
Quotation Content: The Samson of Guido is a noble picture; the figure is as large as life, and the attitude beautiful and full of majesty. He is resting from the slaughter of the Philistines, and stands victorious amidst the havoc he has wrought; the right hand raised, holds the bone filled with water, which he is about to drink, and on which his look is fixed with intense eagerness. How refreshing to turn from the eternal martyrs and prelates to such a theme; they almost realise the complaint of the traveller who came to a strange isle, where the people were very handsome, but their faces were all alike
Riferimento-Bibliografico: Carne, John (1834). Letters from Switzerland and Italy, During a Late Tour by the Author of "Letters from the East" & "Travel in the East".

Quotation Name: The most remarkable thing here is the uncommon beauty of the women; sc…
Quotation Content: The most remarkable thing here is the uncommon beauty of the women; scarcely a plain face is to be seen: whether he looks on a company of women washing linen in the stream, or enters any of the shops, the traveller is alike struck with the loveliness of the features, and the symmetry of the forms. The eyes of the daughters of Bologna are large and dark, their complexions good, though with little colour, and their manners amiable and lively
Riferimento-Bibliografico: Carne, John (1834). Letters from Switzerland and Italy, During a Late Tour by the Author of "Letters from the East" & "Travel in the East".

Quotation Name: The University of Bologna holds a righ rank among the literary institu…
Quotation Content: The University of Bologna holds a righ rank among the literary institutions of Italy. Here the first dissection was performed in the fourteenth century, and galvanism was discovered in our own. Some of its present professors are men of considerable reputation; Orioli, professor of physics, and the celebrated Mezzofanti, of oriental languages.
Riferimento-Bibliografico: Carne, John (1834). Letters from Switzerland and Italy, During a Late Tour by the Author of "Letters from the East" & "Travel in the East".

Quotation Name: Bologna can boast at various times of female professors. In the fourte…
Quotation Content: Bologna can boast at various times of female professors. In the fourteenth century, Novella di Andrea used to supply her father's place in the chair of canon law, and, as she was young and handsome, she is said to have had a curtain before her, that the attention of the students might not be distracted. In the last century, Laura Bassi taught philosophy; and still more lately, the celebrated Clotilde Tambroni, Greek; and at the present moment there are two female professors, one of law and the other of surgery.

Riferimento-Bibliografico: Carne, John (1834). Letters from Switzerland and Italy, During a Late Tour by the Author of "Letters from the East" & "Travel in the East".

Quotation Name: The library of the University contains, it is said, eighty thousand pr…
Quotation Content: The library of the University contains, it is said, eighty thousand printed volumes, and four hundred MSS. There is also a botanical garden, and an agrarian garden, where a course of agriculture is given
Riferimento-Bibliografico: Carne, John (1834). Letters from Switzerland and Italy, During a Late Tour by the Author of "Letters from the East" & "Travel in the East".

Quotation Name: The Instituto must, however, be noticed: among many curious helps to s…
Quotation Content: The Instituto must, however, be noticed: among many curious helps to science, which its numerous rooms contain, we saw the fino collection of astronomical instruments purchased from the effects of Lord Cowper, and the admirable wax representations of anatomical subjects, particularly of the pails of the head.
Riferimento-Bibliografico: Gray, Robert (1791). Letters During the Course of a Tour Through Germany, Switzerland, and Italy in the years MDCCXCI and MDCCXCII.

Quotation Name: The university of Bologna still retains some of its ancient reputation…
Quotation Content: The university of Bologna still retains some of its ancient reputation, as the chief school of civil jurisprudence cultivated in conjunction with the elegant parts of literature.
Riferimento-Bibliografico: Gray, Robert (1791). Letters During the Course of a Tour Through Germany, Switzerland, and Italy in the years MDCCXCI and MDCCXCII.

Quotation Name: If the whole body were delineated with the fame accuracy as were the p…
Quotation Content: If the whole body were delineated with the fame accuracy as were the parts which we saw, and were generally introduced, it might supersede the necessity of exhibiting dead bodies in anatomical schools, which are always obtained with difficulty, and viewed with horror or disgust.
Riferimento-Bibliografico: Gray, Robert (1791). Letters During the Course of a Tour Through Germany, Switzerland, and Italy in the years MDCCXCI and MDCCXCII.

Quotation Name: Public lectures are read at this university, by the professors, withou…
Quotation Content: Public lectures are read at this university, by the professors, without any additional pay, so at least our conductor told us
Riferimento-Bibliografico: Gray, Robert (1791). Letters During the Course of a Tour Through Germany, Switzerland, and Italy in the years MDCCXCI and MDCCXCII.

Quotation Name: This Torre d'Asinello, ascended by 447 steps of a foote rise, seems ex…
Quotation Content: This Torre d'Asinello, ascended by 447 steps of a foote rise, seems exceedingly high, is very narrow, and the more conspicuous from another tower call'd Garisenda so artificially built of brick (which increases the wonder) that it seems ready to fall: 'tis not now so high as the other, but they say the upper part was formerly taken down for feare it should really fall and do mischief.
Riferimento-Bibliografico: Evelyn, John (1819). Memoirs.

Quotation Name: Thence to St.Dominic's, where that saint's body lies richly inshrin'd.…
Quotation Content: Thence to St.Dominic's, where that saint's body lies richly inshrin'd. The stalls, or seates of this goodly church have the historie of the Bible inlaied with severall woods very curiously don, the work of one Fr. Damiano di Bergomo and a frier of that order. Amongst other reliques they shew the two books of Esdras written with his own hand. Here lie buried Jac. Andreas and divers other learn'd persons. To the Church joynes the Convent, in ye quadrangle whereof are old cypresses, said to have been planted by their Saint.
Riferimento-Bibliografico: Evelyn, John (1819). Memoirs.

Quotation Name: The rest of the afternoone was taken up in St. Michael in Bosco, built…
Quotation Content: The rest of the afternoone was taken up in St. Michael in Bosco, built on a steepe hill on the edge of ye Citty, for its fabrick, pleasant shade and groves, cellars, dormitory, and prospects, one of the most delicious retirements I ever saw, art and nature contending which shall exceede; so as till now I never envied the life of a frier.
Riferimento-Bibliografico: Evelyn, John (1819). Memoirs.

Quotation Name: This Citty is famous also for sausages; and here is sold greate quanti…
Quotation Content: This Citty is famous also for sausages; and here is sold greate quantities of Parmegiano cheese, with Botargo, Caviare, &c. which makes some of their shops perfume ye streetes with no agreeable smell.
Riferimento-Bibliografico: Evelyn, John (1819). Memoirs.

Quotation Name: In this Convent there are many excellent paintings of Guido Rheni, abo…
Quotation Content: In this Convent there are many excellent paintings of Guido Rheni, above all, the little cloister of 8 faces painted by Carracci in fresco. The carvings in wood in the sacristy are admirable, as is the inlay'd work about ye Chapell, which even emulates the best paintings, the work is so delicate and tender.
Riferimento-Bibliografico: Evelyn, John (1819). Memoirs.

Quotation Name: This towne belongs to the Pope, and is a famous University, situate in…
Quotation Content: This towne belongs to the Pope, and is a famous University, situate in one of the richest spots of Europe for all sorts of provisions. 'Tis built like a ship, where of the Torre d'Asinello may go for the mainmast. The Citty is of no greate strength, having a trifling wall about it, in circuit neere 5 miles, and 2 in length.
Riferimento-Bibliografico: Evelyn, John (1819). Memoirs.

Quotation Name: the whole towne is so cloyster'd that one may passe from house to hou…
Quotation Content: the whole towne is so cloyster'd that one may passe from house to house through the streets without being expos'd either to raine or sun.
Riferimento-Bibliografico: Evelyn, John (1819). Memoirs.

Quotation Name: Then we went to the Palace of the Legat, a faire brick building, as ar…
Quotation Content: Then we went to the Palace of the Legat, a faire brick building, as are most of the houses and buildings for the whole towne, full of excellent carving and mouldings, so as nothing in stone seemes to be better finish'd or more ornamentall
Riferimento-Bibliografico: Evelyn, John (1819). Memoirs.

Quotation Name: The Piazza before it is the most stately in Italy, St. Mark's at Venic…
Quotation Content: The Piazza before it is the most stately in Italy, St. Mark's at Venice only excepted.
Riferimento-Bibliografico: Evelyn, John (1819). Memoirs.

Quotation Name: I would faine have seene the Library of St. Saviour's, famous for ye n…
Quotation Content: I would faine have seene the Library of St. Saviour's, famous for ye number of rare manuscripts, but could not, so we went to St. Francis's, a glorious pile and exceedingly adorn'd within.
Riferimento-Bibliografico: Evelyn, John (1819). Memoirs.

Quotation Name: Indeede this Citty is full of rare pieces, especialy of Guido, Domenic…
Quotation Content: Indeede this Citty is full of rare pieces, especialy of Guido, Domenico, and a virgin named Isabella Sirani, now living, who has painted many excellent pieces, and imitates Guido so well that many skilfull artists have been deceiv'd.
Riferimento-Bibliografico: Evelyn, John (1819). Memoirs.

Quotation Name: This place has also been famous for lutes made by the old masters, Mol…
Quotation Content: This place has also been famous for lutes made by the old masters, Mollen, Hans Frey, and Nicholas Sconvelt, which were of extraordinary price; the workmen were chiefly Germans.
Riferimento-Bibliografico: Evelyn, John (1819). Memoirs.

Quotation Content: for two whole days, we literally travelled through an uninterrupted succession of cornfields, vineyards and orchards, all in the highest state of cultivation, with the hedges neatly clipped into a kind of trellis-work, and the vines hanging in festoons from tree to tree, or clinging “with marriageable arms" round the branches of each regularly planted and friendly support.

Quotation Name: If its streets are less stately, its public buildings are more picture…
Document: HAZLITT_A journey through France and Italy
Quotation Content: If its streets are less stately, its public buildings are more picturesque and varied; and its long arcades, its porticos and silent walks are a perpetual feast to the eye and the imagination
Riferimento-Bibliografico: Hazlitt, William (1826). Notes of a Journey through France and Italy.

Quotation Name: Here is the Falling Tower, and the Neptune of John of Bologna, in the…
Document: HAZLITT_A journey through France and Italy
Quotation Content: Here is the Falling Tower, and the Neptune of John of Bologna, in the great square

Quotation Name: Going along, we met Professor Mezzofanti, who is said to undestand thi…

Quotation Content: Going along, we met Professor Mezzofanti, who is said to undestand thirty-eight languages, English among the rest.
Riferimento-Bibliografico: Hazlitt, William (1826). Notes of a Journey through France and Italy.

Quotation Name: The college likewise called the Instituto pleased me, which is a found…
Document: Hervey, C. Letters from Portugal, Spain, Italy and Germany in the years 1759, 1760, and 1761
Quotation Content: The college likewise called the Instituto pleased me, which is a foundation for the study of most arts and sciences. The sudden transition from a room full of architecture, to another where there are all sorts of models of fortification, and a third ornamented with things belonging to naval affairs, chemistry or other sciences, is pleasing. Besides there is a good museum of curiosities, and some paintings by no means despicable
Riferimento-Bibliografico: Hervey, C. (1785). Letters from Portugal, Spain, Italy and Germany in the years 1759, 1760, and 1761.

Quotation Name: The city is handsome, tho' the streets are in some places narrow, and…
Document: Hervey, C. Letters from Portugal, Spain, Italy and Germany in the years 1759, 1760, and 1761
Quotation Content: The city is handsome, tho' the streets are in some places narrow, and through most of them on each side runs a colonnade formed like the piazzas in Covent-garden, that a foot passenger may walk about the town in rainy weather with very little wet.
Riferimento-Bibliografico: Hervey, C. (1785). Letters from Portugal, Spain, Italy and Germany in the years 1759, 1760, and 1761.

Quotation Name: All that seemed to me to be wanting were the students, but I suppose t…
Document: Hervey, C. Letters from Portugal, Spain, Italy and Germany in the years 1759, 1760, and 1761
Quotation Content: All that seemed to me to be wanting were the students, but I suppose there are times when they appear, however I saw nobody.
Riferimento-Bibliografico: Hervey, C. (1785). Letters from Portugal, Spain, Italy and Germany in the years 1759, 1760, and 1761.

Quotation Name: This town tho' under the pope, has much the air of a republic, and ind…
Document: Hervey, C. Letters from Portugal, Spain, Italy and Germany in the years 1759, 1760, and 1761
Quotation Content: This town tho' under the pope, has much the air of a republic, and indeed, upon its surrender to the holy see, many of its privileges were preserved.
Riferimento-Bibliografico: Hervey, C. (1785). Letters from Portugal, Spain, Italy and Germany in the years 1759, 1760, and 1761.

Quotation Name: Our third day's journey was to Bologna, which we reached in six hours.…
Document: Mariana Starke - Travels in Italy between the years 1792 and 1978. Vol II
Quotation Content: Our third day's journey was to Bologna, which we reached in six hours. The road hither being hilly, but good, the former part of the country bold and romantic, then latter part rich and beautiful.
Riferimento-Bibliografico: Starke, Mariana (1802). Travels in Italy, between the years 1792 and 1798.

Quotation Name: One of our Party, a young Lady afflicted with weak lungs, was made ala…
Document: Mariana Starke - Travels in Italy between the years 1792 and 1978. Vol II
Quotation Content: One of our Party, a young Lady afflicted with weak lungs, was made alarmingly ill by crossing the Apennine to Bologna, (it being a journey of two days over these mountains, which are quite as cold as the Alps;)
Riferimento-Bibliografico: Starke, Mariana (1802). Travels in Italy, between the years 1792 and 1798.

Quotation Name: The City of Bologna is strikingly magnificent; its environs are charmi…
Document: Mariana Starke - Travels in Italy between the years 1792 and 1978. Vol II
Quotation Content: The City of Bologna is strikingly magnificent; its environs are charming, and, exclusive of the coats of arms being either defaced or taken down from the outsides of palaces and public buildings, this country exhibits no marks of the ravages of war. The most interesting objects to Travellers are — the Sampieri Palace, and the Neptune of Giovanni di Bologna. The former contains a most valuable gallery of pictures
Riferimento-Bibliografico: Starke, Mariana (1802). Travels in Italy, between the years 1792 and 1798.

Quotation Name: The Neptune of Giovanni di Bologna is one of our very finest pieces of…
Document: Mariana Starke - Travels in Italy between the years 1792 and 1978. Vol II
Quotation Content: The Neptune of Giovanni di Bologna is one of our very finest pieces of modern sculpture!
Riferimento-Bibliografico: Starke, Mariana (1802). Travels in Italy, between the years 1792 and 1798.

Quotation Name: This City contains, in its Churches and Palaces, an immense number of…
Document: Mariana Starke - Travels in Italy between the years 1792 and 1978. Vol II
Quotation Content: This City contains, in its Churches and Palaces, an immense number of excellent paintings by the Caracci Family, their Scholars, &c. not mentioned above. In short, so many fine things remain, that those taken away by the French arc scarcely missed.
Riferimento-Bibliografico: Starke, Mariana (1802). Travels in Italy, between the years 1792 and 1798.

Quotation Name: The church bears the name of the Madonna di San Luca, from the famous…
Document: Owen - Travels Into Different Parts of Europe, In the Years 1791 and 1792. With Familiar Remarks on Places--men--and Manners
Quotation Content: The church bears the name of the Madonna di San Luca, from the famous portrait of the Virgin, painted by the hand of the Evangelist, and which it is the boast and glory of the Bolognese to possess.
Riferimento-Bibliografico: Owen, John (1796). Travels Into Different Parts of Europe, In the Years 1791 and 1792. With Familiar Remarks on Places, Men and Manners.

Quotation Name: Bologna is a town, the remembrance of whose beauties will not readily…
Document: Owen - Travels Into Different Parts of Europe, In the Years 1791 and 1792. With Familiar Remarks on Places--men--and Manners
Quotation Content: Bologna is a town, the remembrance of whose beauties will not readily be effaced from my mind
Riferimento-Bibliografico: Owen, John (1796). Travels Into Different Parts of Europe, In the Years 1791 and 1792. With Familiar Remarks on Places, Men and Manners.

Quotation Content: I had heard so much of the celebrity of St. Luke at Bologna, that I immediately requested to be conducted thither. The path to this church is a continual ascent; but pilgrims of all ages, and labouring under whatever infirmities, seemed to tread it without reluctance or fatigue.
Riferimento-Bibliografico: Owen, John (1796). Travels Into Different Parts of Europe, In the Years 1791 and 1792. With Familiar Remarks on Places, Men and Manners.

Quotation Name: This portico has considerable beauty, and still more convenience, as i…
Document: Owen - Travels Into Different Parts of Europe, In the Years 1791 and 1792. With Familiar Remarks on Places--men--and Manners
Quotation Content: This portico has considerable beauty, and still more convenience, as it affords at once the means of shelter and of rest. It was raised by voluntary contribution; six hundred and forty-eight arcades compose the whole range; all of which were built at different periods by the zealous devotion of private persons, or different corporations
Riferimento-Bibliografico: Owen, John (1796). Travels Into Different Parts of Europe, In the Years 1791 and 1792. With Familiar Remarks on Places, Men and Manners.

Quotation Name: The church is an elegant building, and bears on its walls some tablets…
Document: Owen - Travels Into Different Parts of Europe, In the Years 1791 and 1792. With Familiar Remarks on Places--men--and Manners
Quotation Content: The church is an elegant building, and bears on its walls some tablets, commemorative of miracles performed by this marvellous picture. This inestimable treasure is provokingly covered with a cafe, ornamented with jewels, and different offerings of devotion; so that I could only judge of St. Luke's pencil by its miraculous effects.
Riferimento-Bibliografico: Owen, John (1796). Travels Into Different Parts of Europe, In the Years 1791 and 1792. With Familiar Remarks on Places, Men and Manners.

Quotation Name: when religion is addressed to the senses rather than the understanding…
Document: Owen - Travels Into Different Parts of Europe, In the Years 1791 and 1792. With Familiar Remarks on Places--men--and Manners
Quotation Content: when religion is addressed to the senses rather than the understanding, there is nothing too ridiculous to become the object of adoration; and, for my own part, I can discern in the rationality of this species of devotion no difference between the tomb of Mahomet and the cross of Calvary —the image of Diana that fell down from heaven, and the portrait of the Virgin painted by Saint Luke.
Riferimento-Bibliografico: Owen, John (1796). Travels Into Different Parts of Europe, In the Years 1791 and 1792. With Familiar Remarks on Places, Men and Manners.

Quotation Name: A string of beads, which I purchased to escape the suspicion of heresy…
Document: Owen - Travels Into Different Parts of Europe, In the Years 1791 and 1792. With Familiar Remarks on Places--men--and Manners
Quotation Content: A string of beads, which I purchased to escape the suspicion of heresy, entitled me to a little tract, written by the Abbé Calindri, from which I learned the very high value set upon this precious deposit, the solemnity with which it is venerated at Bologna, and the innumerable benefits which have been derived by this city from its residence among them.
Riferimento-Bibliografico: Owen, John (1796). Travels Into Different Parts of Europe, In the Years 1791 and 1792. With Familiar Remarks on Places, Men and Manners.

Quotation Name: This ceremony has also been performed in cafes of public emergency, a…
Document: Owen - Travels Into Different Parts of Europe, In the Years 1791 and 1792. With Familiar Remarks on Places--men--and Manners
Quotation Content: This ceremony has also been performed in cafes of public emergency, as was the cafe in 1779, on account of repeated earthquakes. The consequence was, that though these shocks were so violent, and so frequent as to agitate the country for three years, the city of Bologna sustained no sensible mischiefs from this scourge, which, during its continuance, committed such ravages in the circumjacent cities

Quotation Name: The first object that strikes a traveller on entering the town, is the…
Document: Sir James Edward Smith - A Sketch of a Tour on the Continent, In the Years 1786 and 1787
Quotation Content: The first object that strikes a traveller on entering the town, is the square tower of Asinelli, 307 French feet, or about 110 yards in height, built of brick, in the year 1109; very slender, and of an equal diameter all the way up. It has inclined a few inches from the perpendicular by time. The brick work must have been considerably different from the shameful mud walls so plentifully erecting daily about London.
Riferimento-Bibliografico: Smith, Sir James Edward (1787). A Sketch of a Tour on the Continent, In the Years 1786 and 1787.

Quotation Name: an excellent painting of the Transfiguration, by Ludovico Carracci, on…
Document: Sir James Edward Smith - A Sketch of a Tour on the Continent, In the Years 1786 and 1787
Quotation Content: an excellent painting of the Transfiguration, by Ludovico Carracci, one of the best of his works that I have seen. There is great nobleness in the design, and the drawing and colouring are good, though the latter is a little gray.
Riferimento-Bibliografico: Smith, Sir James Edward (1787). A Sketch of a Tour on the Continent, In the Years 1786 and 1787.

Quotation Name: At the Servi di Maria, St. Andrew adoring his cross is an excellent pe…
Document: Sir James Edward Smith - A Sketch of a Tour on the Continent, In the Years 1786 and 1787
Quotation Content: At the Servi di Maria, St. Andrew adoring his cross is an excellent performance of Al bano's, and a Noli me tangere of the same artist deserves attention.
Riferimento-Bibliografico: Smith, Sir James Edward (1787). A Sketch of a Tour on the Continent, In the Years 1786 and 1787.

Quotation Name: The principal objects of a stranger's curiosity in this town are the n…
Document: Sir James Edward Smith - A Sketch of a Tour on the Continent, In the Years 1786 and 1787
Quotation Content: The principal objects of a stranger's curiosity in this town are the numerous pictures, of which all the palaces and churches are full. Here the productions of the Bolognese school, the works of the Carraccis, of Guido Rheni, Domenichino, Albano, &c. may be seen in the greatest abundance and perfection. We spent four days in contemplating them.

Quotation Content: The day was unfavourable for a view, but we could well distinguish Imola, Ferrara, and Modena ; as well as the hills about Verona, Mount Baldus, &c. seeming to rise abruptly from the dead flat which extends on three sides of Bologna. On the south are some very pleasant hills stuck with villas.
Riferimento-Bibliografico: Smith, Sir James Edward (1787). A Sketch of a Tour on the Continent, In the Years 1786 and 1787.

Document: Sir James Edward Smith - A Sketch of a Tour on the Continent, In the Years 1786 and 1787
Quotation Content: The tower of Garissendi, close to the above mentioned, is not half so high ; but said to have been purposely built leaning eight feet out of the perpendicular. This point however is doubtful, and the guide book of the place fays the foundations have given away ; which is most probable
Riferimento-Bibliografico: Smith, Sir James Edward (1787). A Sketch of a Tour on the Continent, In the Years 1786 and 1787.

Quotation Name: Bologna possesses a very famous public academy, called the Palazzo del…
Document: Sir James Edward Smith - A Sketch of a Tour on the Continent, In the Years 1786 and 1787
Quotation Content: Bologna possesses a very famous public academy, called the Palazzo dell' Instituto, where all the sciences are taught gratis. Here is an ample Museum, Library, and apparatus for Natural Philosophy.
Riferimento-Bibliografico: Smith, Sir James Edward (1787). A Sketch of a Tour on the Continent, In the Years 1786 and 1787.

Quotation Name: The plaster models of gravid uteri, with almost all possible situation…
Document: Sir James Edward Smith - A Sketch of a Tour on the Continent, In the Years 1786 and 1787
Quotation Content: The plaster models of gravid uteri, with almost all possible situations and cases done from nature, are very good, though less beautiful than the anatomical models at Florence.
Riferimento-Bibliografico: Smith, Sir James Edward (1787). A Sketch of a Tour on the Continent, In the Years 1786 and 1787.

Quotation Name: The collection of corals is generally good, especially Isis nobilis, r…
Document: Sir James Edward Smith - A Sketch of a Tour on the Continent, In the Years 1786 and 1787
Quotation Content: The collection of corals is generally good, especially Isis nobilis, red coral, of a variety of shades, from deep scarlet to a blush colour and pure white. One specimen has even red and white in the same piece, as mentioned by Tournefort. There are some fine Spongiœ, and some tolerable Amphibia. A very large very large Testudo coriacea, taken by accident near Civita Vecchia.
Riferimento-Bibliografico: Smith, Sir James Edward (1787). A Sketch of a Tour on the Continent, In the Years 1786 and 1787.

Quotation Name: The minerals are not capital ; but there are some fine real Sicilian j…
Document: Sir James Edward Smith - A Sketch of a Tour on the Continent, In the Years 1786 and 1787
Quotation Content: The minerals are not capital ; but there are some fine real Sicilian jaspers, and a collection, presented by the reigning empress of Russia, of the stones of Siberia.
Riferimento-Bibliografico: Smith, Sir James Edward (1787). A Sketch of a Tour on the Continent, In the Years 1786 and 1787.

Quotation Name: In one of the great halls is an admirable whole-length portrait, in mo…
Document: Sir James Edward Smith - A Sketch of a Tour on the Continent, In the Years 1786 and 1787
Quotation Content: In one of the great halls is an admirable whole-length portrait, in mosaic, of Benedict XIV. executed at Rome. In another room are some curious old pictures, done by the earliest painters of the Bolognese school, some of them of considerable merit. This establishment is entirely owing to Count Marfigli
Riferimento-Bibliografico: Smith, Sir James Edward (1787). A Sketch of a Tour on the Continent, In the Years 1786 and 1787.

Quotation Name: S. Salvatore, whose Corinthian architecture is very majestic, has many…
Document: Sir James Edward Smith - A Sketch of a Tour on the Continent, In the Years 1786 and 1787
Quotation Content: S. Salvatore, whose Corinthian architecture is very majestic, has many tomb stones and holy-water batons of an orange- coloured speckled marble, called rosso di Verona, which I first saw at Loretto.
Riferimento-Bibliografico: Smith, Sir James Edward (1787). A Sketch of a Tour on the Continent, In the Years 1786 and 1787.

Quotation Name: St. John before Zaccharias, with other saints, by Benvenuto Garofalo,…
Document: Sir James Edward Smith - A Sketch of a Tour on the Continent, In the Years 1786 and 1787
Quotation Content: St. John before Zaccharias, with other saints, by Benvenuto Garofalo, is excellent ; but St. John kneels very badly ; he could not possibly support himself as he is represented.
Riferimento-Bibliografico: Smith, Sir James Edward (1787). A Sketch of a Tour on the Continent, In the Years 1786 and 1787.

Quotation Name: There are some small pictures of saints, by Giotto, curious for their…
Document: Sir James Edward Smith - A Sketch of a Tour on the Continent, In the Years 1786 and 1787
Quotation Content: There are some small pictures of saints, by Giotto, curious for their antiquity ; and in the sacristy a pretty good St. Sebastian of Guido Rheni ; and David, with Goliath's head at his feet, by Giovanni Antonio Burrini, in which there is great force of light and shade, like Spagnuoletto's works.
Riferimento-Bibliografico: Smith, Sir James Edward (1787). A Sketch of a Tour on the Continent, In the Years 1786 and 1787.

Quotation Name: At St. Paulo, on the high-altar, under a half dome supported by column…
Document: Sir James Edward Smith - A Sketch of a Tour on the Continent, In the Years 1786 and 1787
Quotation Content: At St. Paulo, on the high-altar, under a half dome supported by columns, are the admirable statues of St. Paul and his executioner, by Algardi. Nothing can be finer than the meek resignation of the saint, who is kneeling in expectation of the fatal stroke, with his face turned from the executioner.
Riferimento-Bibliografico: Smith, Sir James Edward (1787). A Sketch of a Tour on the Continent, In the Years 1786 and 1787.

Quotation Name: St. Dominic's is a long but not inelegant church, in which the most re…
Document: Sir James Edward Smith - A Sketch of a Tour on the Continent, In the Years 1786 and 1787
Quotation Content: St. Dominic's is a long but not inelegant church, in which the most remarkable thing is the shrine of that famous faint, whose apt emblem, as I have already remarked, was a dog with a firebrand in his mouth.
Riferimento-Bibliografico: Smith, Sir James Edward (1787). A Sketch of a Tour on the Continent, In the Years 1786 and 1787.

Quotation Name: There is a chink in the back of the sarcophagus, where devout persons…
Document: Sir James Edward Smith - A Sketch of a Tour on the Continent, In the Years 1786 and 1787
Quotation Content: There is a chink in the back of the sarcophagus, where devout persons have fancied they smelt celestial fragrance. We unfortunately had not faith enough to perceive it ; but I could not help thinking how feelingly we should have been converted, if " Dominic the blacksmith " had thrust out " his tongs red hot " and taken us by the nose.
Riferimento-Bibliografico: Smith, Sir James Edward (1787). A Sketch of a Tour on the Continent, In the Years 1786 and 1787.

Quotation Name: The shrine is gothic, of white marble, extremely rich in sculpture, an…
Document: Sir James Edward Smith - A Sketch of a Tour on the Continent, In the Years 1786 and 1787
Quotation Content: The shrine is gothic, of white marble, extremely rich in sculpture, and terminating upwards in a pyramidal form. On the sarcophagus are an immense number of figures in alto-relievo, of good execution, by an unknown artist. At each extremity of the adjoining altar is a small kneeling angel of white marble.
Riferimento-Bibliografico: Smith, Sir James Edward (1787). A Sketch of a Tour on the Continent, In the Years 1786 and 1787.

Quotation Name: The celebrated St. Cecilia, with St. Paul, Mary Magdalen, and other co…
Document: Sir James Edward Smith - A Sketch of a Tour on the Continent, In the Years 1786 and 1787
Quotation Content: The celebrated St. Cecilia, with St. Paul, Mary Magdalen, and other company, by Raphael ; which has been engraved and often copied. I was a little disappointed in the principal figure, as to its personal beauty and grace ; the Magdalen pleased me much better.
Riferimento-Bibliografico: Smith, Sir James Edward (1787). A Sketch of a Tour on the Continent, In the Years 1786 and 1787.

Quotation Name: The Virgin of the Rosary, by Domenichino ; a confused composition with…
Document: Sir James Edward Smith - A Sketch of a Tour on the Continent, In the Years 1786 and 1787
Quotation Content: The Virgin of the Rosary, by Domenichino ; a confused composition with a great number of figures, of which I cannot understand the design ; but its parts are admirable.
Riferimento-Bibliografico: Smith, Sir James Edward (1787). A Sketch of a Tour on the Continent, In the Years 1786 and 1787.

Quotation Name: Giovanni in Monte is adorned with many pictures, the three principal o…
Document: Sir James Edward Smith - A Sketch of a Tour on the Continent, In the Years 1786 and 1787
Quotation Content: Giovanni in Monte is adorned with many pictures, the three principal of which are, 1st, St. Francis adoring the crucifix, by Guercino; the author of which I should never have guessed. The crucifix is placed on the ground in the forepart, so that the saint's eyes are directed at once to it, and to the crucifix on the altar below. The colouring of this picture is remarkably still ; its expression good.
Riferimento-Bibliografico: Smith, Sir James Edward (1787). A Sketch of a Tour on the Continent, In the Years 1786 and 1787.

Document: Sir James Edward Smith - A Sketch of a Tour on the Continent, In the Years 1786 and 1787
Quotation Content: St. Petronio is a vast old gothic structure, much more resembling a cathedral, though the front is of brick, and unfinished. Most of the buildings in this city are of brick, a great disadvantage to their beauty. In this church is a famous meridian line, made in 1656, and repaired in 1776.
Riferimento-Bibliografico: Smith, Sir James Edward (1787). A Sketch of a Tour on the Continent, In the Years 1786 and 1787.

Quotation Name: The cathedral, or Duomo, is a large majestic building internally, of t…
Document: Sir James Edward Smith - A Sketch of a Tour on the Continent, In the Years 1786 and 1787
Quotation Content: The cathedral, or Duomo, is a large majestic building internally, of the Corinthian order, but with several faults. The arch over the entrance of the tribune is too narrow, and the semicircular niche at the extremity too low. The most remarkable picture here, St. Peter consecrating St. Apollinarius a bishop, by Gratiani, has great merit in the design.
Riferimento-Bibliografico: Smith, Sir James Edward (1787). A Sketch of a Tour on the Continent, In the Years 1786 and 1787.
